headline.main: Revisiting President Obama's Small-Business Tax Cut Claims

docs.abstract: A reader asks whether the Obama administration really has cut small-business taxes 18 times.
docs.snippet: A reader asks whether the Obama administration really has cut small-business taxes 18 times.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House put pressure on states to expand Medicaid but officials also said the states could reverse their decision at any time.

headline.seo: U.S. Advises States to Expand Medicaid or Risk Losing Funds
headline.main: Administration Advises States to Expand Medicaid or Risk Losing Federal Money
headline.print_headline: Administration Advises States to Expand Medicaid or Risk Losing Federal Money

docs.abstract: Obama administration advises states to expand Medicaid or risk losing federal money; at the same time, federal health officials also say states are free to reverse their decision at any time.
docs.snippet: The White House put pressure on states to expand Medicaid but officials also said the states could reverse their decision at any time.

docs.lead_paragraph: Working-age Americans are seeing the doctor less, but how much this has to do with the economy and how much with changing demographics is unclear.

headline.main: Doctor Visits Dropping, New Census Figures Show
headline.print_headline: Doctor Visits Dropping, New Census Figures Show

docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports that working-age Americans are going to to the doctor less frequently than they were 10 years ago; officials say possible reasons for the decline include the poor economy and changing demographics.
docs.snippet: Working-age Americans are seeing the doctor less, but how much this has to do with the economy and how much with changing demographics is unclear.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court bolstered public support for President Obama’s health care law while hurting its own reputation.

headline.seo: Reaction to Supreme Court’s Health Decision a Rarity, Study Finds
headline.main: Health Care Case Is Seen as Helping Law but Hurting Court
headline.print_headline: Health Care Case Helped Law but Hurt Supreme Court, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column looks at study by Prof Andrea Campbell and Nathaniel Persily, who found that by bolstering public support for Pres Obama's health care law, the Supreme Court hurt its own reputation; notes that this complicated and unusual reaction may affect public approval of the justices' future decisions.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court bolstered public support for President Obama’s health care law while hurting its own reputation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The post office, which has missed two deadlines on future retiree health benefits, said it expected net operating losses to be $15 billion for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

headline.seo: Postal Service Defaults on a $5.6 Billion Benefits Payment
headline.main: Distress Deepening, Postal Service Defaults on $5.6 Billion Benefits Payment
headline.print_headline: Distress Deepening, Postal Service Defaults on $5.6 Billion Benefits Payment

docs.abstract: United States Postal Service defaults on a $5.6 billion payment due at the end of September, the second time it has missed a deadline to set aside money for its future retiree health benefits; says it expects net operating losses to be $15 billion for the fiscal year that just ended; officials hope that holiday mail and election mailings will offset some of the losses.
docs.snippet: The post office, which has missed two deadlines on future retiree health benefits, said it expected net operating losses to be $15 billion for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese and foreign companies are investing in elder care and retirement facilities in China, betting that the demographic fallout from its one-child policy will soften traditional attitudes toward out-of-home care.

headline.main: Old Age in China Is a Fledgling Business Opportunity
headline.print_headline: Old Age in China Is a Fledgling Business Opportunity

docs.snippet: Chinese and foreign companies are investing in elder care and retirement facilities in China, betting that the demographic fallout from its one-child policy will soften traditional attitudes toward out-of-home care.

headline.print_headline: A Possible Price to Pay if Doctors Spurn Insurance

docs.abstract: Private health insurance used to be the ticket to a doctor's appointment. Now, many physicians no longer accept insurance and require upfront payment from patients.
docs.snippet: Private health insurance used to be the ticket to a doctor's appointment. Now, many physicians no longer accept insurance and require upfront payment from patients.
